titleStmt.title: A true relation of two great victories obtained of the enemy: the one by Sr. William Brereton in Cheshire, the other by Sir Iohn Meldrum in Lancashire; relating the death of Col. Marrow, and the lists of prisoners taken in both the fights: and of about 1800. horse of Ruperts; as also some remarkable proceedings of Col. Fox, and his cubs; with the late condition of the Lord Generals army in the West. All sent up from good hands to the Parliament, and to citizens of good quallitie. Published according to order.
titleStmt.author: Brereton, William, Sir, 1604-1661.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A TRUE RELATION Of two great VICTORIES OBTAINED of the Enemy: The one by Sr. William Brereton in CHESHIRE, The other by Sir Iohn Meldrum in Lanca≈øhire; relating the death of Col. Marrow, and the Li≈øts of pri≈øoners taken in both the Fights: and of about 1800. Hor≈øe of Ruperts; As al≈øo ≈øome remarkable Proceedings of Col. Fox, and his Cubs; with the late condition of the LORD GENERALS Army in the We≈øt. All ≈øent up from good hands to the Parliament, and to Citizens of good quallitie.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Underhill at the ≈øign of the Bible in Wood≈øtreet, 1644.

div.head: A TRUE RELATION of two great Victories obtained of the Enemy; the one by‚ñ™ Sir William Brereton in Che≈øhire, the other by the LANCA-SHIRE Forces, &c.
div.p: IN my la≈øt I gave you an account of the Skirmi≈øh in Lanca-≈øhire, where the Lord Ogleby, Collonell Myn, and divers other per≈øons of qualitie, Scotts Commanders and Gentlemen were taken pri≈øoners. Since which, upon Sabathday la≈øt, ≈øome of our Forces from Northwich skirmi≈øhed with Collonell Marrow neare Crowton-hou≈øe, wherein wee had a garri≈øon kept, where wee lo≈øt foureteene men, which were taken pri≈øoners. But the enemies lo≈ø≈øe was farre greater, for Collonell Marrow, a ≈øecond Nymrod, received his mortall wound, upon which he is ≈øince dead in Che≈øter. Both he and his Regiment of hor≈øe die at one time. And it is reported by ≈øome, that the bloudy Prince Rupert is going towards the King.

I ≈øhall now acquaint you with Gods continued goodnes unto us, Upon wedne≈øday the 21. of Aug. Sir William Brereton that active, and faithful patriot of his Countrey, ≈øent forth a partie of hor≈øe and foote from Northwych in
Che≈øhire, who marched from thence to Frood≈øham, hoping to have found the enemie there. From thence they marched over the Forre≈øt of Dalamore to A≈øhton, (where we heard they quartered) to have met with them there, but having intelligence that they were at Tarvine, within foure miles of Che≈øter, marched towards them, and meeting ≈øome of their Scouts, pur≈øued them into Tarvine, and there fell upon the enemie and ≈øoone routed them.

Some fled into the Church, others out of the Town towards Che≈øter, but were pur≈øued gallantly by that valiant Captain Zanchy, who commands Sir William Breretons own Troop, within pi≈øtoll ≈øhot of the walls of Che≈øter. A Gentleman of Sir William Breretons Troop, named Mr. Dury, killed one of the enemy clo≈øe at the workes of Che≈øter. And that while they were in pur≈øute of the enemie towards Che≈øter, the re≈øt were not idle in Tarvin: For that worthy valiant Lieutenant Colonell Jones, who commanded the Hor≈øe, behaved him≈øelfe gallantly: and ≈øo did that valiant Major Trevas, who commanded the Foot. The enemy fiered very fa≈øt out of the Church, they tooke ≈øome hor≈øes into the Church, the ≈øervice being very hot, there was one brave hor≈øe they could not get in, but one of the enemy held him in his hand under the Church-wall: A Corporall of Sir William Breretons Troop, named John Cooper, ≈øeeing the hor≈øe, ventured to fetcht him, but they fiered ≈øo fa≈øt out of the Church, that he retreated twice, but the third time ventured up, pi≈øtoled the enemy, and brought away the hor≈øe; which hor≈øe was valued worth four≈øcore pounds. There was taken at the ≈øame time between fourtie and fiftie pri≈øoners, and about three hundred hor≈øe, ≈øome very gallant ones, and when they had done, marched away with their
pri≈øoners and hor≈øes, and lo≈øt but two men. Had not the enemy at Che≈øter had ≈øuch an alarm, and made ≈øuch ha≈øte towards us, we ≈øhould have taken the Church.

list.head: Pri≈øoners taken at Tarvin, the 21. of Augu≈øt, 1644. as followeth.
list.item: James Swinthel of Colonel Chal ‚Ä¢ ro≈ø≈øe Regiment.
Robert Morris, of Captain Swinningtons men.
Rich. Roberts, Lieutenant Colonel Gro≈øvens men.
Thomas Cooper, a little Boy under Lieutenant Colonel Leigh.
Thomas Walker, of Captain Philips Troop.
Robert Hughes of Captaine Woodhas troop.

div.p: And it is to be ob≈øerved, that the very ≈øame day, and at the very ≈øame pre≈øent time, that the Che≈øhire Forces were engaged at Tarvin, that the Lanca≈øhire Forces had a great Victorie over the enemie.

div.head: An extract of a Letter from Lanca≈øhire of credit.
div.p: OUr Major Generall Meldrum having notice of the enemy marched towards Ormskirk made ha≈øt after them, overtook them on Tue≈øday in the evening, on a moor neer Ormskirk, where they ≈øtood in batalia, and upon the fir≈øt charge of our Musket, that were under the command of Col. Booth, they fled, whereupon our Hor≈øe bravely fell upon them, and totally routed them. In the pur≈øuit they took about eight hundred hor≈øe; ≈øome letters report a thou≈øand, and three hundred pri≈øoners. By rea≈øon of the night we could not improve the victory as otherwi≈øe wee might have done.
The Lord Byron, and the Lord Molleneaux were forced to leave their hor≈øes and to hide them≈øelves in a cornfield.

div.head: A Li≈øt of the names of ≈øuch per≈øons of quallity as were taken neer Ormskirk on Tue≈øday, Aug. 20. 1644.
div.p:
Colonel Sr. James Pre≈øtwich,
Captain James Anderton,
Lievt. Col. Cottingham,
Capt. Ecce≈øton,
Capt. Atherton.
Capt. Butler.
Capt. Brookes.
Capt. Lea.
Mr. Worthington, E≈øquire.
Abraham Laughton, E≈øquire.
John Sturbane, Gent. Lievt.
Thomas Mo≈ø≈øoike Lievt.
Walter Chamberlaine, Lievt.
John De Hur≈øt, Lievt.
John Morgrow, Lievt.
Nathan Jones, Liev.
William John≈øon, Coronet.
Edward Stauley, Coronet.
Rich. Wright, Gent. Coronet.
Henry Gilibrand, Coronet.
Peter Bland, Gent.
William Scot, Gent.
Th ‚Ä¢ mas Sherburn, Gent.
_____
Mar≈øhall, Gent.
Arthur Butler, Gent.
James No ‚Ä¢ icon, Gent.
Thomas Wotton, Gent.
John Fox, Gent.
John Fulme, Clerk.
James Bould, Clerk.
John Brown Quarterma≈øter.
Abraham Jones, ≈øervant to Mr. Blunt.
Will. Noricon, Quarterma≈øter.
and about two hundred and fifty common ≈øouldiers.

div.head: Out of a Letter from Che≈øhire.
div.p: THe ≈øtrength of this bloody Prince in his Hor≈øe, is much abated: For at Wel≈øhpoole there was taken by Sir Thomas Middleton, Colonell Mitton, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Che≈øhire Forces, three hundred fourty ≈øix hor≈øes of Ruperts own Regiment. And the ≈øame week was taken by Colonell A≈øhton, at Holland in Lanca≈øhire, two hundred Hor≈øe; and at Pre≈øton in Lanca≈øhire about three≈øcore hor≈øe: And at the la≈øt skirmi≈øh by the Lanca≈øhire Forces at Ormskirk in Lanca≈øhire, abovt nine hundred hor≈øe, and by Sir William Brereton at Tarvin, three hundred hor≈øe, which in all make up neere upon a thou≈øand eight hundred hor≈øe, be≈øides pri≈øoners.

THough ≈øome time be over-pa≈øt, yet I cannot altogether let ≈øleep in oblivion tho≈øe many noble actions of Colonell Fox, not yet in publick view: A little while ≈øince upon the di≈øcovery of the quartering of Worce≈øter Forces in Upton Warren, ≈øome twelve miles from his Garri≈øon, he went forth with a partie of hor≈øe, and tooke in their quarters Captain Milward; one Lieutenant Colonell Dudley, as appeared by a commi≈ø≈øion found in his pocket, Lieutenant Newbery, quarterma≈øter Dod, two Corporals, ten other Souldiers, and twenty hor≈øe; with the≈øe he al≈øo brought a drove of bea≈øts from the Earl of Shrew≈øbury.
A little after he took Captain Knight in his quarters at Stoak, neer Brom≈øgrove.

The 16. of this Augu≈øt, upon intelligence that the Commi≈ø≈øion of Array ≈øate in execution therof at Omber≈øley four miles from Worce≈øter, and 17. from Egber≈øon garri≈øon, de≈øired my Lord of Denbies forces to joyn with him for their apprehen≈øion, which was accordingly attempted, where they took 40. pri≈øoners, divers being men of note, 130 brave hor≈ø, 150 bea≈øts, mo≈øt of the Commi≈ø≈øioners very hardly e≈øcaped, which they had not done, but by rea≈øon of ≈øome delayes of tho≈øe that commanded the Earls forces, being bu≈øied with ≈øome other de≈øignes neerer Worce≈øter, contrary to the Colonels direction and de≈øire, yet notwith≈øtanding by rea≈øon of the Colonel and his cubs pur≈øuit after them over the river Severne, where they were inforced to ≈øwim, hee recovered divers excellent hor≈øe and Armes, and returned with this prize in ≈øafety. In this expedition young Capt. Cotton behaved him≈øelf very valiantly. Upon the 20. of this moneth the Colonell having intelligence of ≈øome Cavaliers to lie in Brom≈øgrove, ≈øent forth a party of hor≈øe under the command of Capt. Tadman, and Capt. John≈øon, who ≈øurprized in that place, Capt. Barn≈øley and his ≈øouldiers, he being a Gentleman of quality, and a Worce≈øter Captain: This noble Colonels practice is ≈øuch, that no Cavalier is heard of in the countrey, but he brings him to his den: neither dare any enemy come out of Worce≈øter to oppo≈øe his proceedings, in≈øomuch that the greate≈øt malignants, and Papi≈øts ≈øeeek to make their peace with us, confe≈ø≈øing their errors.

postscript.p: From the we≈øt ≈øeverall letters expre≈ø≈øe that the King with his whole Army, being farr greater then the Lord Generals, ≈øet upon the Lord Generals Armie on thur≈øday la≈øt Aug. 22. and were gallantly beaten backe with great lo≈ø≈øe, and that both Armies continued fighting by parties for ≈øeverall dayes, and that they ≈øo continued on Sabathday la≈øt when the me≈ø≈øenger came away.
